title: Synthetic Recap
body:
MIAMI — In the heart of a hostile Miami arena, Patrick Ewing turned back the clock and authored a masterpiece. The New York Knicks, fueled by a historic and dominant performance from their captain, dismantled the Miami Heat, 103-85, in a stunning display of individual brilliance.

Ewing was not merely a participant; he was an unstoppable force of nature. The veteran center poured in a game-high 42 points, a colossal figure that dwarfed all other offensive efforts. He was equally immense on the glass, hauling in 22 rebounds to complete a breathtaking 40-20 performance that left the Heat with no answers. Every Miami defender who took a turn was simply another victim in Ewing's path, as he scored from the block, hit his trademark face-up jumper, and controlled the painted area on both ends of the floor.

While Ewing was the undeniable engine, backcourt mates John Starks and Allan Houston provided vital support, chipping in 13 and 12 points respectively to keep the Heat’s defense honest. Miami’s efforts, led by Alonzo Mourning’s 21 points, were rendered irrelevant in the face of Ewing’s onslaught. The Knicks’ defense, anchored by their titan in the middle, smothered Miami into a dismal 37.8% shooting night.

This was more than a road victory; it was a statement delivered through one of the most iconic individual performances in franchise playoff history. On a night defined by his sheer will, Patrick Ewing didn't just win a game—he seized it, commanding the spotlight and powering the Knicks to a crucial 1-0 series lead.
